Dialogue: In any discussion of contemporary America and how its people live, we must inevitably start with -- Manhattan -- New York City, U.S.A!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Manhattan -- glistening, modern giant of concrete and steel reaching to the heavens and holding in its arms seven millions!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Seven millions -- happy beneficiaries of the advantages and comforts this gracious metropolis has to offer...

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Its fine broad streets and boulevards facilitate the New Yorker's carefree, orderly existence.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Kindly, courteous public servants ever on hand to offer a word of friendly advice.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: A transportation system second to none in speed and comfort!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Modern recreational facilities for its children!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: For its adults, the peace and privacy of a day in the sun!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: It's delightful changes in climate!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Its great institutions of learning! Open to all. Free of charge.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I suppose you're wondering what all this has to do with Mr. Blandings and his Dream House? Well, I'll tell you. Jim Blandings is part of the fabric of this town. Born and raised right here, he's as typical a New Yorker as anyone you'll ever meet. At least he was.  And if you want to know the real story, I guess I'm your boy. Cole's my name, Bill Cole. I'm Jim's lawyer and quote, best friend, unquote. Jim's one of those bright young men from Yale. Advertising business, lovely wife, two fine kids, makes almost fifteen thousand a year. Want to know why? Just look up there.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: "When you've got the whim, say 'Wham!'"... Jim Blandings wrote that slogan. Seven magic words that shine like a beacon light for the American housewife!  "When you've got the whim, say 'Wham!'" Jim Blandings' contribution to the American Scene.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: For fourteen years Jim and Muriel had been living in their apartment over on East Seventy-fourth Street. Dialogue: Okay, dad.

Dialogue: Mm.

Dialogue: Okay, dad.

Dialogue: Mm.

Dialogue: Mm.

Dialogue: Muriel.

Dialogue: Mm?

Dialogue: Coffee.

Dialogue: Thank you, dear.

Dialogue: Looking for something, dear?

Dialogue: Why don't you look in your sock drawer?

Dialogue: Oh.  Well, try your underwear drawer.

Dialogue: Muriel, I thought the top two-and-a- half drawers were to be mine! I wish you'd tell Gussie --

Dialogue: The closet! That's where they are. We put them in the closet.

Speaker: jim

Dialogue: Well, there didn't seem to be any room in the drawers...

Dialogue: ...so Gussie and I decided that from now on we'll keep them in a basket on the shelf.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, thanks a lot!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Jim, I do wish you'd make an effort to be a little less clumsy.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'll try, dear.

Speaker: jim

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Excuse...

Dialogue: Excuse...

Dialogue: If you don't mind, dear.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Moment, dear.

Dialogue: Take your time. I can spare the blood.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Oh... cut yourself?

Dialogue: Why don't you get an electric razor?

Dialogue: Ridiculous! Bill Cole's been using one for years.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: He doesn't have my beard!

Dialogue: That's silly. Bill's beard is just as tough and coarse and --

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: You don't have to carry on so. I only said, why don't you get an electric razor?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Because I prefer the cool, clean sweep of the tempered steel as it glides smoothly --

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Stop writing advertising copy! Hurry up, dear, you'll be late for breakfast.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: ...Who did this?

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: I did.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I have repeatedly told you --  -- don't cut up the morning paper until I've had a chance to look at it!

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: I'm sorry, father. It's necessary research.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I suppose this is another of Miss Stellwagon's so-called Progressive Projects?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Now dear, there just isn't any point in sending your children to an expensive school if you're going to undermine the teacher's authority in your own dining room.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'm not undermining anything. I happen to be in the advertising business and keeping abreast of the times is important to me.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: And so is your children's education.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's not the point.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It certainly is.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: It certainly is not!

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Bicker, bicker, bicker.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You eat your cornflakes!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What is it, dear, another English composition?

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: I found one typical of the disintegration of our present society.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I wasn't aware of the fact that our society was disintegrating.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: I didn't expect you to be, father. Miss Stellwagon says that middle- class people like us are all too prone to overlook the pressures and tensions which befall the less fortunate members of our community.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Muriel, I know it's asking a lot, but just one morning I would like to sit down and have breakfast without social significance!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Jim, you really might take a little more interest in your children's education.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: You can't squeeze blood from a turnip.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: All right. All right. I'll listen.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: It's just twenty-four words. But in simple eloquence it mirrors a minor tragedy of our times.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well?...

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Will sacrifice..."

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Go on.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: That's all.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's all?!

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: You don't see it, do you, father?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No. Fellow wants to sell a house so he puts an ad in the paper. What did you expect him to do, take it to the United Nations!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: There must be more to it than that.  Isn't there, dear?

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Certainly, mother. What some people don't see is the whole sordid picture. A poor, honest farmer, pushed to the wall by hardship, soil erosion, mortgages, everybody gobbling, gobbling, gobbling, until finally, in desperation, he is "forced to sell," and stoops to the crass commercialism of newspaper advertising.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh, indeed... crass commercialism... advertising...

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Miss Stellwagon says advertising is a basically parasitic profession.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh, she does?

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Miss Stellwagon says that advertising makes people who can't afford it buy things they don't want with money they haven't got.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Perhaps your Miss Stellwagon is right. Perhaps I ought to get out of this "basically parasitic profession," which at the moment is paying for her very fancy tuition, those extra French lessons, her progressive summer camp and for that matter, the very braces on your teeth!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I wish you wouldn't discuss money in front of the children.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Why not, they spend enough of it!

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Bicker, bicker, bicker.

Dialogue: Hello. Who?  Miss Blandings, there's a Mr. Funkhauser wants to see you.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Funkhauser?  Oh, Mr. Funkhauser!

Speaker: gussie
Dialogue: That's what he says.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Uh -- better ask him to come up.

Speaker: gussie
Dialogue: Says to come up.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Oh -- uh -- darling, Mr. Funkhauser's here.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: ...Who?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: You remember, Bunny Funkhauser, that clever young interior decorator we met at the Collins' cocktail party?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's he doing here?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Well, I imagine he's brought the -- uh -- estimates.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: ...Estimates?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Darling, you know how long we've said we've got to do something about this apartment, and, well, he called last week, and I had him come over, and he's got some simply wonderful ideas!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: There couldn't be two Bunny Funkhausers, could there?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Why, no, dear.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Then this is the same clever young man who's responsible for that zebra- striped monstrosity in the Collins' living room?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: That couch is terribly functional.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Phil Collins told me what he paid for all that function!  If you think I'm going to --

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Darling, please!  Children, you'll be late to school. Run along and --

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Miss Stellwagon says that functionalism in modern furniture --

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Never mind, dear.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: the girls
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Good morning, Mr. Funkhauser. You remember Mr. Blandings?

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: But of course.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: You'll have to pardon my bursting in at this dreary hour --  -- but then Muriel and I thought we ought to talk it over with you before we take the plunge...

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: After all, it's your home, too, and it should reflect you. You know, Man's Castle, all that sort of thing.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Muriel!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Jim, just wait till you hear. He's got some wonderful ideas for the foyer.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Oh, that's out! All out! Changed the whole thing! I just couldn't live with it! I said to myself, "Bunny, what are the Blandings? How shall we do them?" And the answer was perfectly obvious. Very American, very grass roots, very blueberry pie -- that sort of thing.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Mm.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Now first, let's dig into this living room of yours, it's really a dreary.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: We want this room to be very gay, dear. Something in bright reds, yellows and greens.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Red, yellow and green?!

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Oh, come, Mr. Blandings, let's not run away from color.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Not running away --  -- just backing off a little.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Uh -- yes.  Now as I see our room, it's definitely Colonial. You know, cobbler's bench, breakfront, pie cooler, student lamp, hooked rug. But everything in good taste. It must not jump out at you and scream: "Look -- see how antique I am!"

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Heaven forbid.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Of course, these things take imagination. You've simply got to be able to visualize.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: If you'll forgive me, Mr. Funkhauser, what I'd like to visualize -- at this dreary hour -- is how much is this all going to cost?

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Well, really, I hesitate to say. After all --  -- by the time this wall is out we may find --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: This wall is -- what?

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Out. Source of light is from the east. Obviously if our room is to have any function at all --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You're going to tear out the wall?!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Dear, it's a wonderful notion.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Visualize three feet of leaded panes, the rest --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Can you give me a figure?

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Well! Costs aren't what they used to be, you know, and --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Just a figure.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Materials are impossible, labor has just run wild --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Just an overall figure.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Well!... I shouldn't like to be tied down. But I suppose if you must have a figure, I'd say -- mm --  -- somewhere in the neighborhood of seven.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Mm... Seven.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Mm.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That would be seven... thousand?

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Mm.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Mr. Funkhauser, do you have a card?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Jim, we haven't even discussed the rest of the house.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We will, dear.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Well, really, I --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We'll talk it all out and then we'll get in touch with Bunny.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: Well, really, I mean, I was under the impression we'd come to some decision today.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'm sure we will.

Speaker: funkhauser
Dialogue: We-ll!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: So nice of you to come.  Good day.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Now darling, you -- you just don't go to a man like Funkhauser and ask how much it's going to cost before you even know what he's going to do!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No, that would be too logical! Seven thousand dollars! Blueberry pie! I wouldn't put seventy-five cents into this broken-down rat trap!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It's our home, Jim. Betsy was practically born in this apartment.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That does not make it a national shrine!  Seven thousand dollars and not one word about closets.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Closets! You wouldn't even let him get to the bathroom!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I haven't got that kind of money!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: The way you talk, Jim Blandings, you'd think I was some kind of congenital idiot!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Sometimes I'm beginning to wonder!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: You can just get out of here!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's not a bad idea!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Sorry.

Dialogue: Good morning, Mr. Blandings.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: 'Morning.

Dialogue: Hm?

Dialogue: Will that be all?

Dialogue: Well, that's the way it all started. The ad was enough to convince Jim --

Dialogue: -- But Muriel was a little tougher. I guess the corsage did it.

Dialogue: There they are, two little fish from New York -- out in the deep deep waters of Connecticut real estate. That's Smith, the real estate salesman. Mighty shrewd cookie in a quiet sort of way. Never thought he'd get a bite this quick.

Dialogue: Now he's sizing up the catch. "Mm. Let's see. Convertible -- orchids -- must be pretty well fixed. Wonder if they're lookers or buyers?"

Dialogue: They're buyers.  Yes, sir, Smith, looks like you're finally going to unload the old Hackett place. Now first thing is get 'em a little anxious.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Th-a-a-t's right!

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Uh-uh, not yet.

Dialogue: Take it easy, Smith, give 'em a little more line.

Dialogue: Now we're ready to gaff 'em.

Dialogue: Well, folks, there she is -- the old Hackett Place.

Dialogue: Fifty mighty pretty little acres...

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It's simply charming!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: That is, for an old house.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Of course, you understand, Mr. Smith, we're just window shopping, so to speak. Nothing really definite in mind.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Perfectly all right.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Mm. Not a bad-looking place, but it's certainly a lot older than anything we had in mind.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: She's no spring chicken --  -- but that's just what makes her such a buy.

Dialogue: This isn't just old timber, or a virgin stand oak grove other side of the trout stream, or a couple of fruit orchards... You're buying a piece of American history.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You don't say! How's that?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: First year she was built, General Gates stopped right here to water his horses.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh! Old General Gates -- Civil War.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Revolutionary War.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh. Oh, that General Gates. Hear that, honey, General Gates!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Wouldn't that make the house over a hundred years old?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Hundred and seventy come next April.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Now I'm not trying to sell you anything -- all I'm saying is that one of these days someone with a little vision and imagination's goin' to come along, and just steal this place --  and I mean steal it.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Mr. Blandings, I know you can look at that house and just about picture what a couple of coats of paint and a little pointing up here and there can do to it.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Mm.

Dialogue: Hm. Wonder what he meant by "steal?"

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: And I guess I don't have to tell you, Mrs. Blandings, what a woman's touch could do to a place like this.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Well --

Dialogue: It is a nice old house. It just needs someone to love it, that's all.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Yes, sir, you've certainly got to visualize.

Dialogue: Shall we go up and take a look at her?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Well -- I -- suppose as long as we're here...

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I guess it doesn't hurt to take a look.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It does have possibilities. Do you think we can get it?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Like taking candy from a baby.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Now don't lose your head.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Shh. Just keep quiet and let me handle this.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Tell me, Smith, what kind of a price is the owner asking for this old place?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It's wonderful, Jim! That master bedroom with those two closets!

Dialogue: Shh!

Dialogue: Funkhauser could do wonders with this --

Dialogue: Ye-ap.

Dialogue: How'm I doin', George?

Dialogue: Nice timin', Eph. Think we got something here.

Dialogue: They were lookers -- this is the real thing.

Dialogue: If they got five thousand dollars on 'em. don't let 'em get away.

Dialogue: They already offered ten.

Speaker: hackett
Dialogue: Y'don't say... What's my asking price?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Fifteen...

Speaker: hackett
Dialogue: A mite stiff...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I've got 'em measured.  eleven thousand.

Speaker: hackett
Dialogue: Make it eleven thousand five hundred fifty.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Odd kind of figure.

Speaker: hackett
Dialogue: Might as well take the commission out of them instead of me.

Dialogue: "Home, home in Connecticut With a closet to hang up your petticut..."

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: ...Jim?

Dialogue: "No hustle or fuss No Fifth Avenue bus --"

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Uh -- Jim?

Dialogue: Hm?

Dialogue: I was just wondering, dear. Ten thousand dollars is such an awful lot to offer --

Dialogue: That is, for two people who don't know anything at all about real estate, or anything...  I mean, don't you think perhaps we should have asked someone's professional advice?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Like... say... a lawyer?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Well, Bill knows about these things and --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Muriel, for once in my life I'm going to make one small decision, on my own, without the legalistic machinations of Mr. Bill Cole.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It seems very peculiar that when your very best friend happens to be one of the very cleverest young lawyers in New York City --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Muriel, I don't want to hear another word about Bill Cole!  Well, did your mother tell you about the house?

Dialogue: Yes.

Dialogue: Well?

Dialogue: Miss Stellwagon says the current craze for modernizing old farmhouses is a form of totem worship.

Dialogue: Did it ever occur to you two that there may be some remote, intangible subjects upon which your Miss Irma Stellwagon is not the final authority?

Dialogue: Why don't we buy a Solaxion house?

Dialogue: ...You know it's just barely conceivable -- What kind of a house?

Dialogue: Solaxion. It's built on a mast like a tent and it revolves with the sun.

Dialogue: Oh, it... revolves... with the sun?

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: That's right.

Dialogue: Who lives next door -- Buck Rogers?!

Speaker: joan

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Muriel --

Dialogue: Children, you haven't even seen this house yet.

Dialogue: Personally, I'd like a Crane Mobile home. It comes all folded up and all you do is plug it in for electricity and water and --

Dialogue: Now just a minute!  Do you want to spend the rest of your lives in chromium tents and portable merry-go-rounds? This house was built before our country became a nation. It has dignity. It's -- it's --

Dialogue: Special delivery, Mr. Blandings.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: From Smith!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Mm.

Dialogue: Well?

Dialogue: Oh, dear. Maybe we should have gone a few dollars higher.

Dialogue: He's bluffing. Simple as that.

Dialogue: For ten thousand dollars we could get a Rockford Trailer and a Zamboni Power Unit. It's kitchen, bathroom and air conditioning all rolled up into --

Dialogue: Muriel, I'll let him push me to ten thousand, two hundred, but not a penny more!

Dialogue: "Dear Mr. Blandings: While your offer of ten thousand two hundred is still not acceptable to Ephemus Hackett -- "

Dialogue: "Dear Friend Blandings --"

Dialogue: "My dear Friend Smith --"

Dialogue: "Dear Blandings --!"

Dialogue: "Dear Smith - !"

Dialogue: What do you think, Bill? Steal, huh?

Dialogue: What do you mean?

Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Dialogue: Dear, I told you. I said we should call Bill --

Dialogue: Never mind, Muriel!  All right, just what's wrong with this deal?
