Dialogue: First time around you offered ten thousand dollars for fifty acres, right?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What of it?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: That's two hundred dollars an acre. I know that part of Connecticut and one hundred dollars an acre is standard top-gouge price to city slickers. When the natives sell to each other it's around forty or less.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Forty dollars an acre!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The man's entitled to a fair profit.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Not two hundred and eighty-four percent.  And besides, you're not getting fifty acres, you're only getting thirty- five, more or less.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Where does it say that?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I refer to a rather obscure post- script on the back of the second letter from Friend Smith.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: "Incidentally, Mr. Hackett has been a little over-optimistic about the acreage. It will probably survey somewhere in the neighborhood of thirty-five acres, more or less, but I feel sure..."

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: All right, so it's thirty-five! What's the difference? Do you know how many tennis courts you can get on thirty- five acres?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You're not spending eleven thousand five hundred dollars for tennis courts!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's not the point!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: That's precisely the point. We're going to write this Hackett a strong letter and tell him he can either kick in with those fifteen acres, reduce the price, or find another sucker.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We'll do no such thing! I'm not going to queer this deal over fifteen broken- down acres!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: We were just going window shopping and so far it's cost us eleven thousand five hundred dollars and they even made us pay the commission!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You don't understand business.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You mean extortion.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I wonder if we could get another two year lease on the apartment?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Now wait a minute! You can't measure everything on a slide rule. This house has certain intangibles.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Like what, for instance?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Like antique value, for instance! It just so happens that General Gates stopped right there, at that very house, to water his horses.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I don't care if General Grant dropped in for a scotch and soda -- you're still getting rocked!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That was a different war!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I think Bill's absolutely right.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Let me explain something. To both of you. For fifteen years I've been cooped up in a four room cracker box! Just getting shaved in the morning entitles a man to the Congressional Medal for bravery.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: That doesn't make this a good buy.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Bill -- Muriel and I have found what I am not ashamed to call our Dream House. It's like a fine painting. You buy it with your heart, not your head. You don't ask, how much was the canvas, how much was the paint? You look at it and you say, "It's beautiful... I want it," and if it costs a few pennies more you pay it -- and gladly -- because you love it and you can't measure the things you love in dollars and cents!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well -- that's how I feel about this place. And when I sign those papers Saturday, I can look the world in the face and say, "It's mine! My house! My home! My thirty-five acres!"

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Our house. Our home. Our thirty-five acres...

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: ...more or less...

Speaker: judge quarles
Dialogue: "...thence along said stonewall fence forming the East boundary of said Lansdale Road, N 20 27' E, 21.84 feet to the end of said stonewall fence, thence along a wire fence, N 16 31' W, 78.66 feet to a dead twenty- inch chestnut tree, thence westward to said stonewall fence, to a total of thirty-one and a half acres --"

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What was that? How many acres?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Thirty-one and a half.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I was under the impression your property was thirty-five acres, Mr. Hackett.

Speaker: hackett
Dialogue: It is... more or less.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You see, Mr. Blandings, when you signed the purchase agreement it was subject to traced map attached. Surveyed to an even thirty-one and a half acres.

Speaker: judge quarles
Dialogue: Anything wrong?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: It's nothing, Your Honor, just a few less tennis courts.

Speaker: judge quarles
Dialogue: "...to have and to hold to him, the said Grantee, his heirs and assigns to his and their own proper use and benefit forever."

Speaker: judge quarles
Dialogue: Subject to a six thousand dollar mortgage held by Ephemus Whittaker Hackett...

Speaker: shrunk mills
Dialogue: 2 Mi.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Congress ought to pass a law. When a man buys a house in Lansdale County there's a prize -- he gets ten percent off if he can find it.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What in the world are "Shrunk Mills?"

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: They are probably mills that have shrunk.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Well, you certainly aren't much of a help.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Look -- you really want to find that house of yours -- it's no problem.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Just pretend you're one of General Gates' horses and you're thirsty... Now where would you go for a drink of water?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Well, I must admit it's a very beautiful thing.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: The house and the lilac are just the same age, Bill; if the lilac can live and be so old, so can the house. It just needs someone to love it, that's all.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: It's a good thing there are two of you -- one to love it and one to hold it up.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What'd your engineer say when he checked over the foundation and that roof?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Who needs engineers? This isn't a train, you know.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I just saw it move.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: This house has been standing since the second year of the Continental Congress. You take one look at it and shingles start to fall off!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Look -- let me do you a favor. I've got a client, crackerjack structural engineer, Joe Apollonio; he practically built the George Washington Bridge single-handed.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Thanks a lot, but we're not building a bridge.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: He's the follow who advised the Government not to raise the Normandie -- they didn't listen to him, cost them five million dollars.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You have my word, if I were raising the Normandie, I wouldn't make a move without Apollonio.  Now would you like to come inside and look around?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: No thanks, I'll just stay out in the car and listen to "Life Can Be Beautiful."

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I think you'd better contact Mr. Apollonio.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It has charm, hasn't it, Mr. Apollonio?

Speaker: apollonio
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Of course, any small changes would have to conform with the character of the countryside.

Speaker: apollonio
Dialogue: Mm-hmm.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: And yet still be functional.

Speaker: apollonio
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, uh, what's your professional opinion?

Speaker: apollonio
Dialogue: Tear it down.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Tear it down??!

Speaker: apollonio
Dialogue: If your chimney was shot and your sills was okay, I'd say go ahead, fix her up. If your sills was shot and your chimney was okay, again I'd say go ahead, fix her up. But your sills are shot and your chimney is shot.

Speaker: apollonio
Dialogue: Take a look at the way she sags.

Speaker: apollonio
Dialogue: So I say don't throw good money after bad -- tear it down.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Thanks a lot.

Speaker: apollonio
Dialogue: It's okay.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Bill Cole and his experts!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Darling, we'll get our own experts.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: And so they got their own experts. Mr. Simpson said --

Speaker: simpson
Dialogue: Tear it down.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: On the other hand, Mr. Murphy said --

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: I think you'd better tear it down.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: And then just to be a wee bit different, Mr. Jones said --

Speaker: jones
Dialogue: Tear it down!

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: And that's how our friend, Mr. Simms, came into it.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Of course you could fix up that old house. You can fix up any structure that's still standing. The sills and floors couldn't be worse, I grant you, and I guess you'd have to jack up that west corner at least three feet to make it level. Need new chimney. New roof. Complete new plumbing.  Too bad you didn't buy it ten years ago. Could have fixed it up in jig time then, and it would have made some sense.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Uh-huh... mm-hmmm... uh-huh.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Fact is, before you're through, it would be less expensive to tear the old place down and build a new one, same size.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Mm. New house...  New house.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: You mean... for the same money... we could build a brand new house?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: It certainly wouldn't cost any more.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Hm... New house...

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Just... what sort of thing do you have in mind?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Well, I imagine the type of house you'd want would be something in quiet good taste, two story, frame and brick veneer construction -- modern, but of course fitting in with the architectural traditions of the countryside.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, I -- What do you think, Muriel?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I think it sounds fine.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Perhaps you'd like to see a basic floor plan --  -- something like this.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: First floor. Living room, study, dining room, kitchen, service porch, maid's room -- upstairs three family bedrooms with two adjoining baths.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It's very nice, I'm sure, but -- uh -- well -- doesn't it seem just a little bit conventional?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yes, Simms, if we were going to build a house we want it -- well, you know -- just a little bit different.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Yes, of course.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Now, for instance --

Speaker: jim's voice
Dialogue: -- here in the study if we could just push out this wall a little -- and put in a built-in bar we could --

Speaker: muriel's voice
Dialogue: Excuse me, dear --

Speaker: muriel's voice
Dialogue: These bedrooms. They do seem rather small. And, of course we'd have to have a little dressing room -- and --

Speaker: jim's voice
Dialogue: And closets, Simms, lots of closets.  If there's one thing this family needs, it's closets.

Speaker: simms' voice
Dialogue: If I might make a suggestion --

Speaker: muriel's voice
Dialogue: And bathrooms, Mr. Simms. Each bedroom must have at least one bathroom.

Speaker: simms' voice
Dialogue: But that would be four bathrooms, Mrs. Blandings --  I think I'd better point out to you --

Speaker: jim's voice
Dialogue: Just a minute. Do you think --  we might manage a little playroom in the basement, nothing tremendous, you know, something like this --

Speaker: simms' voice
Dialogue: Well, it's always possible, but at the moment our fundamental problem --

Speaker: muriel's voice
Dialogue: You know, a little utility room where I can be alone, and sew, or sulk, or on a rainy afternoon...

Speaker: jim's voice
Dialogue: Pardon me, dear. On that playroom, Simms, not too small. You know, plenty of room for ping-pong, darts, nice big poker table...

Speaker: simms' voice
Dialogue: If you don't mind, I --

Speaker: muriel's voice
Dialogue: ...And off the kitchen, I'd like a little flower sink just to putter around in...

Speaker: jim's voice
Dialogue: ...And a terrace off the study, with an owning and little outdoor fireplace...

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: We-ll... let's just see what we have here. In the first place --

Speaker: simms' voice
Dialogue: -- I'm afraid you've got the upstairs about twice as big as the downstairs.

Speaker: jim's voice
Dialogue: It's all those bathrooms.

Speaker: muriel's voice
Dialogue: It is not, it's all those closets.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: By extending this breakfast room you've eliminated the possibility of any stairs going to the second floor.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh, you can just shove those stairs in anywhere.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Which, of course, might be very warm in winter, but otherwise of doubtful utility.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: You could always move the chimney somewhere else, couldn't you?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: We-ll...  Look, I think I know just about what you two have in mind. Why don't I go ahead with some preliminary plans and --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You do that, Simms, but remember, we've got to hold it down to ten thousand.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: That, I can tell you right now, is impossible. Even with a considerable trimming of the things you've indicated, I don't see how we can bring it in for less than twelve or twelve-five.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Twelve-five!  Well, I guess we're not going to quibble about a few pennies one way or the other.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: No, you'll find Mr. Blandings never quibbles about pennies.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: And -- uh -- have you any notions about how you'd like the old place taken down?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Why don't we just blow on it?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: There's a good local house wrecker. I'll have him contact you.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Fine. You just shoot ahead with those plans, and remember, try to keep it down to ten, ten-five.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Well -- we'll try.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: There's one good thing about getting that old relic down. Those original beams and everything -- this time somebody pays us.

Speaker: hackett
Dialogue: Them beams is worth money. You payin' him, or he payin' you?

Speaker: wrecker
Dialogue: He's payin' me.

Speaker: hackett
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: wrecker
Dialogue: A thousand.

Speaker: hackett
Dialogue: A thousand!

Speaker: wrecker
Dialogue: He squawked, but he paid.

Speaker: hackett
Dialogue: Hmm. I guess maybe I got a little somethin' comin' too.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Okay, boys, let her go!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, so far it's cost us thirteen thousand, three hundred and twenty- nine dollars and forty-five cents.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: But we've got the nicest vacant lot in the state of Connecticut.

Speaker: simms' voice
Dialogue: Something will have to give somewhere, that I know.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It's impossible. I don't see how we can cut another inch.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Honey, you heard Simms. As the house stands now it's over fifteen thousand dollars!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Well, it just doesn't seem possible --  for a house with such small rooms.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Mrs. Blandings, I've already explained. It's not only the size of the rooms so much as it is the number. You see, our primary problem is one of cubage --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's right, dear, cubage.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh --  just a figure of speech.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: But what does it mean?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: -- go into a cubic foot. Go on, Simms.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Now is it absolutely essential for each of your daughters to have her own room with two closets and a separate bath?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yes. You see, er, my daughters are, er, approaching womanhood, and, er --

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Perhaps what you need is not so much a house as a series of little bungalows.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Hmmm.  What about that silly flower sink? We could eliminate that.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I beg your pardon.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Or that sewing room upstairs, that's certainly a waste.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: If we're going to eliminate anything, we'll lose that ridiculous play room in the basement with that great big poker table.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Honey, I've got to have some relaxation.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: We've got thirty-one and a half acres. Go out in the back and do a little gardening.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Sure, and get poison ivy!

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: If I may interrupt, I'd like to suggest that none of these are really major eliminations. Now if we could do with one less bathroom on the second floor --

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I'm sorry. We couldn't possibly.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Mrs. Blandings, a simple bathroom, eight by ten by eight with grade A fixtures will cost around thirteen hundred dollars.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I refuse to endanger the health of my children in a house with less than four bathrooms.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: For thirteen hundred dollars they can live in a house with three bathrooms and rough it!

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Look, perhaps the most practical thing would be --

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Oh, look, we're in the Lansdale paper!  "Historical Society Blasts Vandalism!"

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Muriel, Simms explained to you. We've just got to cut, cut --  What's that?

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: "Censure Vote Passed re Destruction of Famed Hackett Edifice."

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, isn't that just too bad! Let me see that.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What's so funny.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Bildad Prutty! Muriel, I've got to send this to the New Yorker!

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Read on, father.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Read on, father.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: "...which Ephemus Hackett testified was the lowest reasonable price he could accept as --"

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: ...Twenty-six hundred dollars.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: And what did we pay, father?

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Eleven-five, with the commission.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Muriel, isn't it time for those children to be in bed?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Now girls, I don't want to tell you again.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Excuse me.

Speaker: jim's voice
Dialogue: Twenty-six hundred dollars!

Speaker: simms' voice
Dialogue: I wouldn't be too concerned about Mrs. Prutty and her committee. After all, it's your property and if you want to tear it down --

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Why, Bill!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Well, you've done it again'. Once, just once, why don't you come to me and find out if it's all right, if it's legal, before you go barging off and run yourself smack into another jam!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's eating you?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: And I must say, Simms, I hold you equally responsible!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What? What happened?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: I'm afraid I don't understand.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Did you let this idiot tear down that house?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What if he did? What of it?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Reconstruction was unsound and totally impractical.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I quite agree. But you're dealing with a man who doesn't think before he acts, who goes off half-cocked!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What is it? What did I do?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You're an architect! You must have been aware of the legality involved.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What? What legality?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You knew there was a mortgage on that house.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: I assumed as much.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What happened? What are you talking about?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: And you know the requirements in regard to a mortgage where there's demolition intended!

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Certainly. But since you were his lawyer, I naturally assumed --

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: With a man like this you can't assume anything!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Just one minute! I am entitled to know what I did! This is America! A man's guilty until he's proven innocent --

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: It's the other way around, father.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You go to bed!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Girls!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Bill, I've had a very trying day. Would you mind telling me in clear, concise English just what crime I've committed -- and why?!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: In clear, concise English, you tore down a house on which another man holds a mortgage without first getting his written permission.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, I -- I did?!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: And in such case, the mortgagee can demand the full payment of said mortgage upon demand --  and Mr. Ephemus Hackett so demands! Six thousand clams! And he wants them now!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Now?!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You've got ten days.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: For six thousand dollars we could have had a Solaxion house and a Crane Mobile home.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Muriel!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Girls, say your good nights and off to bed without another word.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Good night, Mr. Simms. Uncle Bill.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Miss Stellwagon says the problems of the parents should be the problems of the children.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: You keep that in mind, dear. It'll help prepare you for motherhood.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Perhaps we'd better let the plans go for the time being and --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No, Simms, I'll work this out. You go ahead with your final plans and let's see some estimates.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: And we'll just forget about that extra bathroom.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Very well. You'll hear from me as soon as possible. Good night.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Six thousand dollars!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What'll you do for collateral on your building loan?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I don't know, turn in my insurance policies or something.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Now, Jim, you can't do that.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What if something should happen? You can't leave the children unprotected.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'm not dead yet! And if I die, there's plenty left to take care of them.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Not if you cash in your policies.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I'm sure it won't be necessary. I'll see the boys at the bank. Maybe you can put up your insurance as collateral. If necessary, I'll sign a personal note.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Thanks, Bill.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: And Jim, do me a little favor. The next time you're going to do anything, or say anything, or buy anything, think it over very carefully, and when you're sure you're right -- forget the whole thing. Good night, Muriel.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Good night, Bill.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What a wonderful friend.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's with this kissing all of a sudden?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Just because a man is helpful in a business way, it doesn't give him extra-curricular privileges with my wife!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: That's a fine thing to say about a friend of fifteen years!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, I don't like it. Every time he goes out of this house, he shakes my hand and he kisses you.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Would you prefer it the other way around?!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, I don't like it, that's all! Why is he always hanging around? Why doesn't he ever get married -- or something?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Because he can't find another girl as sweet and pretty and wholesome as I am.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well -- it -- it doesn't look right. There are limits to friendship and --

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Darling, let's not be silly about this. It's not Bill, it's the house you're upset about.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I suppose so.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Do you think it's worth all this?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Of course, darling. We're not just building a house -- it's a home. A home for ourselves -- and our children -- and maybe our children's children.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: It's getting awfully crowded with only three bathrooms.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Well -- here are the estimates. Before you look at them, I think I'd better explain --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Don't bother, Simms.  I'm getting to be an old hand at this sort of --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Jumping H. Mahogany --!!

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Now obviously these bids are way out of line, that is, all except John Retch and Son at twenty-one thousand.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Twenty-one thousand!

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: And with some judicious cutting, I think we can pare that down to eighteen.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: We've only asked for the barest necessities --

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Frankly, with all the extras you two have --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Never mind.  Now, if you'll excuse us.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Where are we going?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I am going out to get my head examined! Then, if I don't jump off the Brooklyn Bridge, I'm going to find the owner of our building and sign a twenty-year lease!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's the name of that contractor?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, things are certainly humming.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I said, humming.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What's going on over there?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's Mr. Tesander. He's digging our well.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Well? What happened to the trout stream, with that pure, clear, cold mountain water?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I decided against it --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The trout stream --  didn't seem practical.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It wasn't exactly a decision, dear.  We discovered the trout stream dries up in August and the rest of the year it's polluted.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, anyway, I'd rather have artesian water. It's healthier. Calcium -- vitamins -- artesian --

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What's wrong with that steam shovel?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Better take a look.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Jim!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Thank you, dear.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's the matter, Mr. Zucca? Something wrong?

Speaker: zucca
Dialogue: How do you lika that? Broka my bucket. Two times this week I broka my bucket?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What did you do, strike a boulder?

Speaker: zucca
Dialogue: Atsa no boulder, atsa ledge.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What does that mean?

Speaker: zucca
Dialogue: Meansa we gotta blast!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Blast?

Speaker: zucca
Dialogue: Blast. Witha dynamite.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What do you mean, dynamite?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What do you mean, "What do you mean?" Mr. Zucca just explained. He's going to use dynamite and blast until he gets rid of the rock.

Speaker: zucca
Dialogue: Atsa no rock, atsa ledge.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What Mr. Blandings means is -- what precisely is a ledge?

Speaker: zucca
Dialogue: Ledge. Lika bigga stone, only a- bigger.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Like a boulder?

Speaker: zucca
Dialogue: No, like ledge.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: ...Like a ledge.

Speaker: zucca
Dialogue: But you don't gotta worry. Only cost twenty-four cents a cubic foot, plussa dynamite an'a fuse.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: But how far will you have to blast?

Speaker: zucca
Dialogue: Harda tell. Might be a lilla baby ledge -- mighta run the whole toppa the mountain.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: At twenty-four cents a foot? Do you realize what that means?!

Speaker: zucca
Dialogue: Meansa we gotta blast.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, anyway, our house will never sink.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: If it does, we can always get Mr. Apollonio. He raised the Normandie.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: "Come to peaceful Connecticut --  Trade city soot for sylvan charm."

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: How long does that go on?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I don't know.  Three weeks now at four dollars and fifty cents a foot.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I think I'd better have a little talk with Mr. Tesander.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh -- Mr. Tesander --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Mr. Tesander!

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Yep?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: How's it coming?

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: It's comin'.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No -- no -- I mean --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Mr. Tesander!

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Yep?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What I meant was -- how far down are you?

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Oh -- 'bout a hundred and ninety feet.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well -- isn't that pretty deep?

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Yep.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Do you think maybe you'd better try another spot?

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Up to you.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I mean -- well, have you hit anything yet at all?

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Hit some limestone yesterday.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Is that good?

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: That's bad.

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: And right now it looks like we're coming into some shale.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's bad?

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: That's good.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh...

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: 'Course it might turn out to be sandstone.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's bad?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's good?

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Can't tell. Might be good. Might be bad. One thing you know -- you got plenty of shale, sandstone and limestone.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: ...I see.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: On a hot day there's nothing like a nice cool limestone shower.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Mr. Tesander, just for the record, of course, what ever happened to water?

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Oh, it's there, all right.  Just got to be patient.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: If you ask me, this project's getting a little out of hand.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: with a few minor deviations, I know exactly what every penny's going to cost.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Two pennies.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: And just what does that mean?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Meansa we gotta blast.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You see, Mary, the average fellow who builds a house doesn't know where he stands from day to day -- but I do things a little differently. With a few minor deviations I know exactly where every penny is going --

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Bill! Come in, come in.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Can I talk?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Sure. What's up?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: While I was in there with Dascomb the conversation kind of got around to you and -- uh --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Well, he didn't say in so many words that ever since you started with that house you haven't turned in a decent piece of copy, but --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: But you kind of got the feeling...

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: ...that if I told you, you'd know that he knew that you knew that he knew... that you knew... or something.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's he worrying about? The deadline's three months off. I've always --

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Hello? Yes. Just a minute.  Mrs. Blandings calling from Lensdale.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yes, Muriel. What? What's that? Tesander struck water! Say that's wonderful!  We've finally got our well.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Congratulations.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Come on, Bill, we'd better get out to Lansdale.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Anything wrong?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Mary, have you ever seriously considered building a house?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Well, no offense, Mr. Blandings, but my boy friend says that anybody who builds a house today is crazy.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You stick with that boy, he's got a great future.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You mean you hit a spring, a bubbling spring right here in our cellar?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: It'll have to be diverted before Retch here can lay his cement.

Speaker: retch
Dialogue: May take a while. Pumps are over in Jersey.

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Tsk, tsk, tsk.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Water, Mr. Tesander.

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Yep.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: At six feet!

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Yep.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: And over there, just thirty-two yards away, you had to go down two hundred and twenty-seven feet to hit the same water.

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Yep.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: How do you account for that, Mr. Tesander?

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: We-ll, way it seems to me, Mr. Blandings, over here the water's down around six feet and over there it's -- uh --

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What's this, another closet?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: This happens to be our dining room.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Not the dining room, dear, the living room.  There's the fireplace.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Then where's the dining room?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Maybe it's that little room off the hallway.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's the breakfast nook.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It's not the breakfast nook, it's the powder room.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Do me a favor -- don't ever invite me here for a meal.

Speaker: first workman
Dialogue: I don't figure this Blandings at all. If you gotta build on the windiest hill in Connecticut, why do you have to pick the windiest side of the hill?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You know these New York millionaires -- they're eccentric.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I think I'd like to go outside.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: After you, Rockefeller.

Speaker: carpenter
Dialogue: Just the man I want to see. Would you step over here a second?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I'll browse around upstairs.

Speaker: carpenter
Dialogue: On them second floor lintels between the lally columns, do you want we should rabbet them or not?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The -- second -- floor -- lallys?

Speaker: carpenter
Dialogue: The second floor lintels, between the lallys.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh. Oh, the lintels between the lallys?

Speaker: carpenter
Dialogue: Yeah. From the blueprints you can't tell. You want they should be rabbeted?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Un -- umm. No, I guess not.

Speaker: carpenter
Dialogue: Okay, you're the doctor.  Hey, fellas, you got any of them rabbeted lintels set, rip 'em out!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: It sounded less... expensive to say no.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Stop it! Stop it!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Okay, fellas, let's quit!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Now look what you've done.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I mean, there's no point in walking off a job just because... a woman makes a silly little remark.

Speaker: workman
Dialogue: It's Saturday, mister. We quit at twelve o'clock. This ain't a chain gang, you know.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I'm just sick. From the outside this house looks like a grain elevator, and on the inside everything's miles too small.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's what?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: That noise -- listen.  It's coming from the closet!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: The door blew shut. I got locked in.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Impossible. I had this closet built especially for myself. The lock opens from the inside.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Maybe for Houdini -- not for me.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Nothing to it. A child could work it. Look, I'll show you.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You see, it just takes a little good old Yankee know-how.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: You know, dear, it's just possible the lock worked for you and not for Bill.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Ridiculous. Even you could do it.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Come on, I'll show you.

Speaker: jim's voice
Dialogue: Go ahead, dear, just open it.

Speaker: muriel's voice
Dialogue: I don't seem to be able to ---

Speaker: jim's voice
Dialogue: Here, let me show you! You just take the knob and turn it clockwise.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Nothing like that good old Yankee know-how.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Hey! Hey! Somebody let us out of here!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Oh, dear.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Monday morning.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: If I could just get over to that scaffolding...

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Seems a shame but I guess it's the only way...

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What are you going to do?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Don't get panicky, I'll get you out of here.  Here, hold this over the window.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Stand back, Muriel.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Ready?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Roger.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: In case of emergency -- break glass. Come on, Bill.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Funny... always worked before. Huh. I wonder...

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Dad, do you suppose I could have a chemistry lab in the basement?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Sure, why not?

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: I think it's awful. Smelling up the house with those horrible chemicals.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Never mind, Betsy.  Dear, I'm going up to the place this afternoon to see about landscaping. Bill's driving me.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What do you mean, Bill's driving you?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Why do you always say, "what do you mean," when you know perfectly well what I mean and what you mean?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I mean that every time I turn my back Bill Cole's driving you some place or something.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: He's only being helpful.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I thought he was a lawyer! Why isn't he out suing somebody?

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Bicker, bicker, bicker.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Another word and you don't get your laboratory.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Well, that's something!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We'll just see about that!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What is it, dear?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Jim, what's the matter?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: ...Well?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We're moving in thirty days.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: So-came thirty days -- and they moved.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: I mean -- we moved.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: That's the wrong road! Any fool knows that!

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Well, there she is, bright and shining -- and just about complete -- the residence of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Blandings.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Not bad at that.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: All right! -- Everybody out.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Guess you can't blame them for feeling just a little bit proud.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Look -- he wants to carry his wife across the threshold. Romantic, isn't it?

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Ooops! I guess I meant "corny."

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Uh-uh. Watch that sacroiliac. Fifteen years since you've done this sort of thing.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Whew! Nice work, Tarzan. Now, let's see if you can make it into the hall.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: That's right. Go right in. Don't pay any attention to the sign.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Don't mind me, buddy, I just got through varnishing that floor.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Whose bright idea was this?

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: She just wanted everything to be nice and shiny on the day they moved in.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Stop painting that floor and put some planks down in here, or some thing!

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Okay, mister, but take it easy. The Republicans ain't in yet, you know.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Oh, fine! A house without windows! We'll just see about that!

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: Look out for those papers!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Where's Simms?

Speaker: workman
Dialogue: Around back trying to figure out what to do about them windows.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's the problem? You put windows up.

Speaker: workman
Dialogue: Not these. They don't fit.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh, they don't, don't they?

Speaker: retch
Dialogue: Oh, Mr. Blandings, you'd better look these over.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's this about the windows?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: I'm afraid there's a little slip-up. These windows seem to belong to a Mr. Landings in Fishkill, New York. I talked to Mr. Landings this morning.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, has he got mine?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: No, he seems to have some windows that belong to a Mr. Blandsworth of Peekskill.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Where are my windows?!

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: As near as we can figure out they've either been sent to a Mr. Benton in Evanston, Illinois, or a Mr. Bamberger of Phoenix, Arizona.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What are we supposed to do -- live the rest of our lives in a house without windows?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: It'll just be a matter of a few days.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What's a "Zuz-Zuz Water Soft-N-R"?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: How should I know?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You've got one.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I will not have any such piece of equipment in my house!

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: I'm afraid I authorized that, Mr. Blandings -- to save your boiler and water pipes.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: From what?!

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Rust. The plumbing man assures us the water from your well is the most corrosive in his entire experience in the trade.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Another first!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, if it's necessary, put it in! We're moving in today, you know and --

Speaker: retch
Dialogue: It's in.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh.  Then get me the bill for it!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You've got it.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: All right then.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Now I want the living room to be a soft green.  Not quite as bluish as a robin's egg, but yet not as yellow as daffodil buds.

Speaker: pedelford
Dialogue: Mm.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: The best sample I could get is a little too yellow, but don't let whoever mixes it go to the other extreme and get it too blue. It should just be sort of a grayish yellow green.

Speaker: pedelford
Dialogue: Mm-hmm.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Now the dining room I'd like yellow. Not just yellow, a very gay yellow.

Speaker: pedelford
Dialogue: Mm-hmm.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Something bright and sunshiny.  I tell you, Mr. PeDelford, if you'll just send one of your workmen to the A&P for a pound of their best butter and match it exactly, you can't go wrong.

Speaker: pedelford
Dialogue: Mm.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: This is the paper we're going to use here in the foyer.  It's flowered but I don't want the ceiling to match any of the colors of the flowers. There are some little dots in the background, and it's these dots I want you to match. Not the little greenish dots near the hollyhock leaf, but the little bluish dot between the rosebud and the delphinium blossom. Is that clear?

Speaker: pedelford
Dialogue: Mm-hmm.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: The kitchen's to be white. Not a cold, antiseptic hospital white -- a little warmer but not to suggest any other color but white.

Speaker: pedelford
Dialogue: Mm.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Now for the powder room, I want you to match this thread.  You can see it's practically an apple red. Somewhere between a healthy Winesap and an unripened Jonathan.

Speaker: pedelford
Dialogue: Mm.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Will you excuse me?

Speaker: pedelford
Dialogue: Got it, Charlie?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Green, yellow, blue, white, red.

Speaker: pedelford
Dialogue: Check.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Joan, you know father was to take care of the heavy dishes.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: He disappeared. I haven't seen him for an hour.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Where's Uncle Bill? I just checked the timetable -- he's going to miss his train.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: If they've run off somewhere it certainly isn't very --

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Heavens!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I thought you were going to take care of it.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I thought you were.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: You're going to miss your train, Uncle Bill! It leaves Lansdale in twenty-five minutes.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Isn't there a later one?

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Not till the Commuter's Special tomorrow morning at six-fifteen.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You mean seven-fifteen.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: No, Dad, six-fifteen.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What about the seven-fifteen I'm supposed to take to the office every morning?!

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: There's a little asterisk. The seven- fifteen only runs Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Muriel!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Oh, dear, don't tell me I read it wrong.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's fine! For the rest of my life I'm going to have to get up at five o'clock in the morning to catch the six-fifteen, to get to my office by eight, which doesn't even open until nine -- and which I never get to until ten!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Perhaps if you started earlier you could quit earlier.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: So I could get home earlier to go to bed earlier to get up earlier!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Maybe you can have the railroad push the train up to four-fifteen -- then you won't have to go to bed at all!

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Uncle Bill, you're going to miss your train!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Jim, you clean up this mess. I'll drive Bill to the station and pick up some cold cuts for dinner.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: You'd better hurry!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Kind of hate to leave that little place. Just four walls and a couple of mothballs, but to me it'll always be home.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: So long, Bill.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: It's certainly going to be fun this summer when Uncle Bill comes up for his vacation.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: We'll get in a lot of doubles.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Hmm?  What are you talking about? Bill's going to Europe.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: No, he's not. I heard him and mother talking. He's going to move his vacation up and take a place in Lansdale.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: All right, come on, come on. Get busy.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I'll scout around and find you a place in Lansdale.  Now, you're not going to change your mind about coming up?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Don't worry, I'll be on the job.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It won't be easy. I promise you a Cook's tour of every lamp maker, rug weaver, and antique shop in Lansdale County.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: When I married you two I suppose I took you for better or for worse.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Good old Uncle Bill.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Good old Uncle Bill.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Now look what you've done!

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Father, the first principle of lighting a fire is to see if the flue is open. A three-year-old child knows that.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Next time we want a fire I'll send out for a three-year-old child!  Get that stuff cleaned up and go in and help Gussie set the table. It's getting late.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Look, Dad, your fraternity pins.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Pins? I only had one.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: There are two of them here.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: All right, all right. Just put them away.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: William Cole! It must be Uncle Bill's!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Huh?  Hmmmm.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Mother's diary when she was in college. It's slightly torrid.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Let's see.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's none of your business!

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: I'd say mother and Uncle Bill were somewhat of an item!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Now go in there and help Gussie with the table.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: What about --?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'll take care of that. Now, shoo, shoo.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: To shave.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Tonight??

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: While I can still trust myself with a razor. At six o'clock in the morning I'd probably cut my throat. Goodnight.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Excuse...

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Excuse...

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Muriel, do you have to do that now?!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: There's no need to be so irritable just because you have to shave at night.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'm not irritable!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Well, you're certainly something! You haven't said a civil word all evening.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Sometimes a man doesn't feel like talking.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What is it, dear? Something down at the office?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Have you got the new slogan for "Wham"?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: It's not due yet!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Well, it's something. You're certainly upset about something. I can always tell.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'm not upset.  It's just that I don't happen to approve of falsehood and deception. Particularly in my own wife.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh, nothing. It's just that I distinctly remember your telling me you gave back Bill's fraternity pin fifteen years ago.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, did you or didn't you?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Did I, or didn't I what?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Give it back to him.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Of course I did. If I said I did, I did.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Then perhaps you'd have the goodness to explain how this happened to fall out of your jewel box?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's so funny?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: You! You're jealous! You're standing there with your face full of soap and you're jealous.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: If you were so crazy about the guy, why didn't you marry him?!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Because I wasn't in love with him!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's not what you said in your diary!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Oh, now you've been reading my diary!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well -- it happened to fall open and... I... happened to look at it. It... just happened.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I'll just bet!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: It's all over the book so why don't you admit it? You were in love with Bill Cole!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Don't be absurd! Of course I was in love with Bill. In those days I was in love with a new man every week.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Then why did you marry me?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I'm beginning to wonder!  Maybe it was those big cow eyes of yours or that ridiculous hole in your chin! Maybe I knew that some day you'd bring me out to this thirty- eight thousand dollar icebox with a dried-up trout stream and no windows! Or maybe I just happened to fall in love with you -- but for heaven's sake, don't ask me why!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: ...Muriel?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: ...Honey?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Would it do any good to say I'm sorry?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well -- I am. I acted like a schoolboy and I'm sorry.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Oh, Jim!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Why don't you take the soap out of your ears?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Why do I love you so much?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Darling, it's awfully late.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Maybe you ought to go down and lock the doors.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What for? The windows are all open anyway.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Jim, you have to get up at six o'clock.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yes, I guess so.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Goodnight, dear.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Goodnight.

Speaker: bill's voice
Dialogue: And so the days sped by -- and the bills -- and the extras -- and as the house approached forty thousand dollars, Jim approached his deadline for the new slogan. It was almost a photo finish.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You'd better send out for coffee and sandwiches,... It looks like an all night session.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: What did he say?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Tomorrow morning.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Well, I guess you'll just have to dream something up -- good or bad.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I rather got the impression it had better be good.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Funny how you look forward to the little things. Rain, for instance.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: For a month now, I guess I've been looking forward to the first rainy night at the house.  Oh, well.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Thank heavens! The children.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Stay put. You look too comfortable.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Oh, I'm not Mr. Blandings. Cole's the name, Bill Cole.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Friend of the family. Wet clothes. Just came in out of the rain.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I'm Mrs. Blandings.

Speaker: jones
Dialogue: How do. Mrs. Williams just called. Says your phone's out of order. Wanted me to tell you the water's rising and they've got the bridge roped off. Girls'll spend the night over at her place.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Thank you. I was beginning to get concerned. Can I make you a cup of tea?

Speaker: jones
Dialogue: No, thanks. Better be gettin' back 'fore I have to swim for it. 'Night, Mrs. Blandings.  'Night, Mr. Bl--

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Cole. Bill Cole. Friend of the family. Just came in out of the rain.

Speaker: jones
Dialogue: Well -- 'Night.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Goodnight... and thanks so much.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: That's fine. No bridge. How do I get back to Lansdale?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: You'll just have to spend the night right here.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Muriel, really! With your husband in New York and your children away -- think of my reputation.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Don't worry, Snow White, you'll be as pure and unsullied in the morning as you were the night before.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: That's the story of my life.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Poor Jim, he sounded so worried before. I certainly hope he comes up with something.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Don't worry about the man who gave the world "When you've got the whim, say Wham!"-- This well will never run dry.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: "Compare the price, compare the slice, Take our advice -- Buy Wham!"

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: "If you'd buy better ham. You'd better buy Wham!"

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: It's Boyle Petroleum. "If you'd buy better oil, You'd better buy Boyle."

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: "This little pig went to market As meek and as mild as a lamb. He smiled in his tracks When they slipped him the axe He knew he'd turn out to be Wham!"

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: "...knew he'd turn out to be Wham!"

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I don't know... I don't know.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Home, to get some sleep -- and I'd advise you to do the same.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: But -- but you haven't --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Suppose I haven't! This isn't the only job in town!

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: But -- but -- what'll I tell Mr. Dascomb?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You just tell him!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: 'Morning, dear.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Darling, you must be exhausted. How did it go?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Fine. Fine.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Is... everything all right?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Hello, Simms, what brings you out with the morning dew?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Just dropped by to check the blueprints. Some extras came in from Retch this morning and there're a couple of things I thought we ought to go over together.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Really. What are they?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Well, let's see.  Few little things here, all right, I guess. "Mortising five butts -- a dollar sixty-eight."

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Let's not quibble about that. A man's entitled to mortise a few butts now and then.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Extra nails and screws -- three dollars, eighty-nine cents.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Petty larceny, but let him get away with it.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Now there's one here I frankly don't understand. Ah, here we are.  "Changes in closet, twelve hundred and forty-seven dollars." Did you authorize that?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, we probably told him to --  Twelve hundred and what?!

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Forty-seven dollars. Changes in closet.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What's this notation: "Refer to Detail Sheet Number one thirty-five?"

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Far as I remember, that would be something in the back of the house. Let's just take a look.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Ah, here we are. It isn't a closet at all. It's off the back pantry... Mrs. Blandings' little flower sink.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Oh... Mrs. Blandings' little flower sink.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: You didn't authorize any changes, did you?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Well... they certainly weren't changes.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What -- have -- you -- done?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: I haven't done anything! And what I did was... just nothing at all.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What -- have -- you -- done?!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Well --  All I did was one day I saw four pieces of flagstone left over from the porch that were just going to be thrown away because nobody wanted them and I asked Mr. Retch if he wouldn't just put them down on the floor of the flower sink and poke a little cement between the cracks and give me a nice stone floor where it might be wet with flowers and things. That was absolutely all I did.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's all you did?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Absolutely. Just four little pieces of flagstone.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Did you by any chance authorize a drain?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Of course I didn't. All I said was I wanted a nice stone floor and Mr. Retch was just as nice as could be and said, "You're the doctor," and that's all anybody ever said to anybody about anything.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: ...Well?

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: All right, I think I can tell you what happened. First, the carpenters had to rip up the flooring that was already laid. Those planks run under the whole width of the pantry, so Retch had to knock the bottom out of the pantry wall to get at them.

Speaker: simms' voice
Dialogue: Then he had to chop out the tops of the joists under the flower sink space to make room for a cradle. I guess he bought some iron straps and fastened them to a big pan to give him something to hold the cement. What with that added load on the weakened joists, I'll bet he had to put a lally column down there for support, too.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: It was just four little pieces of flagstone, and I only ---

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Quiet!

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Well, the main soil pipe runs under there on wall brackets, so Retch had to get his plumbing man back to take out a section so he could get that cradle set. I guess that meant he had to change the pitch of the soil pipe from one end of the house to the other.  'Morning, Mr. Cole.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: 'Morning. Hello, Jim.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Hello, Bill.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: The bridge was roped off and Bill had to stay last night.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Slept like a rock.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'm delighted.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: And then, of course, there are hot and cold water pipes hooked to the joists right under that pantry. They go up to the wing bathroom on the second floor, and I'll bet my bottom dollar he had to relocate them.

Speaker: simms' voice
Dialogue: And I guess the electrician had to rip out about sixty feet of armored cable between the main panel and the junction box by the oil burner, including the two hundred twenty volt cable that goes to the stove.

Speaker: gussie
Dialogue: 'Morning, everybody. Whew! What a night!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Where have you been?

Speaker: gussie
Dialogue: Lansdale. Couldn't get back across the bridge.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You... weren't here last night?

Speaker: gussie
Dialogue: They weren't letting anybody across that bridge, Mr. Blandings.  I passed the girls over at the Williams. They'll be along any minute.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Thank you, Gussie. You'd better get breakfast started.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Where were we?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: We were at the two hundred twenty volt cable that goes to the stove.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Just a minute.  You mean the children weren't here last night either?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: How could they be, dear? The bridge was closed.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I just came across it.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Well, it was closed last night.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: It's open now!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: If you'll all excuse me -- I -- I think I'll just go up and slip into something a little more comfortable.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Well, that's about the size of it --

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: -- except that Retch had to repair the pantry wall and that meant getting a plasterer back. And of course, he couldn't have broken through that wall --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: All right, Simms, all right. We'll take care of it.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: I'll admit it's a little steep. But I'll try to get Retch to knock a hundred dollars off the bill. If I can't get that, I'll certainly try for seventy-five.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: If he doesn't go for seventy-five, I'll take a stab at fifty.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You do that.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Anyway, I'm almost sure we can get twenty-five.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Well. Good day.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Now dear, you're upset, you've got a lot of things on your mind --

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Muriel, there's only one thing on my mind -- This house -- and how fast we can get rid of it!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: That's not what you're thinking.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Maybe it's not. Maybe I'm thinking I was once a happy man!  I didn't have a closet, I didn't have three bathrooms, but I did have my sanity, a few dollars in the bank, two children who loved me and a wife I could trust!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: That's a fine thing to say!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I also had a job at Danton and Bascomb, something I don't happen to have at the moment!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Jim!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's right, I've resigned! We're starting all over again! From scratch! And without this house!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: You love this house!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I hate it!

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: You don't mean that.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Every word of it! Anybody who builds a house today is crazy! The minute you start, they put you on the list. The All-American Sucker list! Everywhere you turn they've got a hand in your pocket. If you take out their hands, they find more pockets!  It's a conspiracy, I tell you, a conspiracy against every man and woman who want a home of their own! Against every boy and girl who were ever in love!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What do you want?!

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Well, Mr. Blandings, there's a matter of twelve dollars and eighty-six cents.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Wouldn't Retch like a little something? Maybe Zucca could use my new dinner jacket? It's open house, Mr. Tesander! Help yourself! If this isn't enough I'll come over to your place and do some odd chores. Maybe I can mow your lawn or scratch your back!

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: You don't understand, Mr. Blandings. This twelve dollars and eighty-six cents -- you don't owe me, I owe you.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: ...W-what was that?

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Found I overcharged you. Almost three feet.

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Better count it. I think it's all there.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Thank you very much, Mr. Tesander.

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Well, I guess I'd better be gettin' along.  I'll tell Mr. Zucca about the dinner jacket.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Oh, Mr. Tesander -- could you give me a lift to town?

Speaker: tesander
Dialogue: Yep.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Be right with you.

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: What did you mean before about losing your job? Will we really have to sell the house?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I don't know, dear... I don't know.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: In case anyone's interested, I'm leaving for town.  If you want to count the silverware, I'll wait.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Bill, be patient with me. Maybe one of these days I'll grow up.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What happened to him?

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: Twelve dollars and eighty-six cents.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Mind if I say something?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You know, I've kind of been the voice of doom about this whole project. Every step of the way I was firmly convinced you were getting fleeced, bilked, rooked, flimflammed and generally taken to the cleaners. And maybe you were. Maybe it cost you a whole lot more than you thought it would. Maybe there were times when you wished you'd never started the whole thing. But when I look around and see what you two have here -- I don't know.  Maybe there are some things you should buy with your heart and not with your head. Maybe those are the things that really count... See you around.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: 'Morning, everybody!

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Hi, Dad! How come you're not at the office?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'm on a... kind of a vacation.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: You mean you got fired?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, not exactly, I --

Speaker: muriel
Dialogue: We'll discuss it later.

Speaker: gussie
Dialogue: Come and get it! Breakfast everybody.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Good! I'm starving! What are we having, Gussie?

Speaker: gussie
Dialogue: Orange juice, scrambled eggs and you- know-what.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Ham?

Speaker: gussie
Dialogue: Not ham -- Wham!  If you ain't eatin' Wham, you ain't eatin' ham!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What did she say?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Darling, give Gussie a ten dollar raise!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Drop in and see us sometime.
